issues.description: The problem statement says the endpoint GET /persons returns a Set of all persons, but the template and solution code expose GET /persons as returning a List<Person> (PersonResource returns ResponseEntity<List<Person>> and PersonService.getAll() returns List<Person>). This is a cross-artifact mismatch in the collection type used for the main listing endpoint and can confuse students about the expected return type and what they should use in their code/tests.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the collection type consistent across artifacts. Either (A) update the problem statement to state that GET /persons returns a List of persons (preferred minimal change), or (B) change the controller and service signatures to return Set<Person> (e.g., ResponseEntity<Set<Person>> and PersonService.getAll() -> Set<Person>, converting personRepository.findAll() into a Set) and update tests accordingly. Ensure the documentation and example responses use the same collection type.

issues.description: The problem statement explicitly says the endpoint GET /persons returns a Set of all persons, but both the template and solution implementations use java.util.List for the GET /persons endpoint and the service method getAll(). This mismatch between the documented collection type (Set) and the implemented type (List) can confuse students: they may look for or try to use a Set-returning API or be uncertain which collection semantics (ordering, uniqueness) are required. The naming/identifier here is the collection type used to represent the same conceptual entity "collection of persons."
issues.suggested_fix: Align the problem statement and the code on the same collection type. The least disruptive fix is to update problem_statement.md to describe the endpoint as returning a list/collection instead of a Set (e.g., replace "returns a Set of all persons" with "returns a list (List) of all persons" or "returns a collection of all persons"). If you prefer Set semantics, update the template and solution signatures: change PersonResource.getAllPersons to ResponseEntity<Set<Person>> and PersonService.getAll to return Set<Person> (converting the repository result to a Set), and update tests/documentation accordingly. Prefer updating the problem statement to "List/collection" to preserve the existing code and tests.
